title: How to find a reputable literary agent to get my book to a publisher - Quora

response.answer_text: Here is my stock answer for anyone who asks me how to get published: PUBLISHERS I'm going to assume you have taken writing classes and seminars and have written a spectacular, sharp novel that contains no grammatical errors, has no cliches, has a fresh plot, compelling characters, hooks where they are supposed to be, that you have inserted twists, that your pacing is perfect, and you wrote killer dialogue. I'm going to assume you know the market, what is expected in your genre, and have written the correct number of pages according to the guidelines. I'm going to assume your chapters are the correct length for the type of story you wrote, that the scenes are stellar, and that there are no POV problems. If you haven’t done all of that … don’t bother reaching out to a publisher. Remember your competition is every known and successful author in the world who are also contacting publishing houses and pitching their books. How can you compete with them if your book isn’t up to par? If your book is really ready, here's what you do: There is a difference between an agent, who tries to find a publishing house to take on your book, and an editor at a publishing house who also might offer a book contract. Let's start with the publishing houses. In the publishing world there are five major publishing houses: Penguin Random House (Penguin, Dutton, Putnam, Random House, Alfred A. Knopf, Doubleday, Crown, etc.) , Simon & Schuster (Poseidon, Pocket, Threshold, etc.), HarperCollins (Harlequin, etc.), Macmillan (St. Martin's Press, Tor, etc.), and Hachette (Little, Brown & Company, etc.) Very few of the Big 5 publishers and their subsidiaries accept unsolicited manuscripts. You must query them first, which involves you knowing how to write a killer one-page letter asking them if they are interested in reading more of your novel. If they are, they will request 3 chapters and a synopsis of your book, which requires you to know how to write a synopsis. Then you wait. I waited for 18 months once (and I had an agent) for Harlequin to send me a rejection letter. There are many, many smaller publishing houses. Yes, they don't have the power and reach that the Big 5 does, but you have to start somewhere. My suggestion is to scout around the Internet and find an agent that represents the type of book you have written. Query him/her and see if you can get a contract with an agency. Then let the agent do the job of shopping your book around to publishers. They have the contacts and the knowhow. Yes, you pay them a fee from your sales. But you wouldn't have had any sales without them. And they don't market to the 'little publishers'; not enough money in that for either of you. Also make sure your book is ready. Have it read by other writers and take their comments seriously. One good site to try is querytracker. com. That is a free website that lists agents and publishers and tells you which ones take which genres and what their requirements are and how to submit to them. Not every agent in the world is listed here but there's around 1400 of them on this site. Do your homework and find publishers on that site that take on new writers that don't have an agent. Query them. If you don't know what a query letter is Google it...there are many sites that show you how to write that letter. Smaller publishing houses may be more willing to take a chance on a new writer than one from the Big 5. If you are lucky enough to get a request for 3 chapters and a synopsis, and you don’t know how to write a synopsis … check out this blog: Great Synopsis Checklist | Writers In The Storm To get the attention of an agent or editor you MUST write a book they want to represent. With that said, only query the ones that represent the genre your book is in. The query letter is the industry standard. Learn to write a killer query that hooks the agent and makes him/her want to read your work. I always (even though it says not to) include the first 5 pages of my ms (manuscript) along with the query. If they are interested, they will read them. If they read the first few pages and I can hook them, I'll get a request for a partial, which is 3 chapters. So there's your in... a killer query and a grab-em-by-the-throat first five pages. Just make sure the rest of the ms is as good as the first 5 pages. The other way to get the eye of an agent is to attend local writing conferences where agents are setting appointments. Most times, unless your book is just awful, they will ask for you to send the first 3 chapters as a courtesy because you attended the conference. There's your in. Make sure your chapters are sharp and fresh. The conference has a fee, but if you can fit it in your budget it is well worth it in just the lectures and knowledge you are going to gain. Here is an interesting diagram of what’s what in the publishing industry. The Big Five US Trade Book Publishers Also check this website out. It was updated October 7, 2018. https://www.thebalance.com/the-big-five-trade-book-publishers-2800047 Check out my e-book for more writing tips: Write Better Right Now: Creative Writing Tips http://amzn.com/B00IHIWUDC Only $1.99.

First, look in the acknowledgments section of your favorite books. See who the author thanks. If they mention their agent, there’s where you start. Then, buy a one-month subscription to Publishersmarketplace.com and research that agent and others who also represents the same kind of work. Third, go to a conference like the writers digest conference in New York and sign up for the pitch session. There, you can meet 10 agents in one morning. It helps you figure out if your pitch is working, and get feedback if it’s not. Also, they may request pages from you. It is a great way to skip the queue/line. Much more efficient and simply contacting them without meeting them first. Another option is to check out the #MSWL Which stands for manuscript wish list. Agents don’t want you to pitch them there on Twitter but they will tell you what they are looking for. Most of the agents who post there are reputable. But you should still do your research. Also read Janet Reid’s blog Query Shark for everything you need to know about contacting agents. She takes no prisoners and it is well worth reading.

For us the answer is to look at Jeff Herman’s Guide to Book Publishers Editors and Literary Agents. This book has been in print since the 1990s with over 500,000 copies sold. Literary Agents are asked very detailed questions, some to establish their personalities, but they take the time to fill out the questionnaires, which his very valuable to writers seeking agency representation. We also hear complaints pretty quickly if someone slips past our scrutiny. In the past the best way to determine a legitimate literary agent was to see if they charged anything. Many agents now are doing consulting work to supplement their income. This is different from a reading fee which is required before they consider representation. That is a red flag. You want to look at track record as well to determine if they are really selling books. But don’t rely solely on complaints made about a particular agent unless there are many of them that seem to have merit. There are many disgruntled writers who blame the literary agent for not creating their career for them and they will complain to “get even.”

Writer’s Market is your best bet. How? By submitting query letters. Why? Because very few publishers accept unsolicited submissions from writers. When? As often as you can, just read the fine print regarding simultaneous submissions. What? Exactly what the agent asks for - no more, no less. Who? The agent that specializes in your genre. There are genre specific agents out there, that have contacts in certain publishing houses. But . . . No buts! I started querying when you still had to print your sample pages, include a SASE (self-addressed-stamped-envelope), and stick it in the mail. My first 200 rejections cost me a small fortune in stamps, ink, and envelopes. Nowadays, most are okay with an email, so you have it way easier. Prepare to receive some rejections, a bunch of form letters, and, if your writing is any good, a few request for samples. Do not expect a contract after you send in a query letter. Be realistic, optimistic, and determined. It’s a job, not a baby.

Even though the literary world is a business, a certain amount of intuition is involved. With this in mind, think of writers whose voice resonates with yours. These aren’t necessarily writers you love, but writers with whom you feel an intuitivel connection—maybe you recognize that they think the way you think or have the same kind of musical tone in their work (something you’ll hear). Many of them thank their agents in forwards or afterwards and these are the people who will resonate with your work and find you the right editor. I got my agent in a different way but she got a contract with an editor at a large press whom several people thought would like the book

Start by conducting a little research with comparable books. Pick the top three (or more) titles that are closest to the book you’ve written. Go to the acknowledgments page to see if the literary agent is listed. Repeat with the other two books. If the literary agent is not listed, Google “Literary Agent for (type in the title). That should lead directly to the agent or to an article quoting the agent. Keep a list of these names. Go to querytracker.net to look up agent contact information, as well as any other titles they represent that fit your genre. Once you have a list, follow the agent’s requirements and write a strong query letter (see how-to tips on the same website). In your letter reference the book they represent that is similar to your book. This process will help narrow down your list to agents that may respond to your query. Best of luck! :)

If you are under 26, Bombadil Publishng is likely to help you. Essentially they are traditional publishers and if the book is good enough they will publish it right away. if it still needs editing, you will be signed up on MageQuill , a creative tool where mentors help you get the quality right (again, there is no cost). If you are over 26 try Writers’ market. and send queries to publishers. Self publishing can work, but essentially it is very expensive and they do not really critique it properly. However, if you are good at marketing or in a niche market, self publishing could work.

I am a published author with two books. One by Time-Warner, and the other by Barrons Books. You can use Writer’s Markets, which is an annual publication. It lists literary agents and what type of work they specialize in placing. It also lists magazines that publish articles and what kind of material they want. You should be able to find a reputable agent using Writer’s Market.
Get yourself a copy of Writer’s Market, and read it in it’s entirety, then you may be enquiring about how you self publish. Good Luck! Robert
